alert_summary.description: Very dangerous wind chills in the region; main impacts are frostbite risk and transportation issues from extreme cold rather than snow accumulation. (In effect through Saturday morning, 2026-01-24 11:00 AM EST.)

meteorology.overall_conditions_summary: For Rockford, MI, the provided forecast focus (Sunday 2026-01-25) is cold, dry, and overcast with no snow or ice expected and good visibility. Temperatures remain well below freezing all day (low near 6F overnight, rising to mid-teens by afternoon) with light winds (generally 5–9 mph, occasional higher gusts), producing wind chills near/just below 0F at times. From a Michigan snow-day standpoint, there is no accumulation, no plow-timing issue, and no ice signal in this forecast window—so a snow day on Monday 2026-01-26 is unlikely based on this data alone. The only notable operational concern would be lingering slick spots from prior events plus extreme cold exposure risk at bus stops, but the extreme cold warning shown ends Saturday and there are no active winter precip signals on Sunday to force closures.

similar_weather_patterns.pattern_description: Post–Arctic blast / high-pressure dominance: very cold air settles in after a burst of lake-effect and/or freezing drizzle, then skies stay mostly cloudy/overcast with little to no new precipitation. Roads are generally plowed, but residual slick spots can persist (especially bridges, overpasses, shaded/rural roads) because temps stay well below freezing.

Extreme-cold-driven operations impacts (wind chills near or below -15°F) without heavy snow: districts consider closures/delays mainly for student safety at bus stops and reliability (diesel buses, battery issues), rather than impassable roads. This is more likely when the worst wind chills align with the morning commute window.

Light-ice risk tail (after freezing rain/freezing drizzle episodes): even with zero new precip forecast, any untreated moisture refreezes overnight; a small number of closures/delays occur if there’s documented black ice on commute routes.

seasonal_context.typical_conditions_for_date: Late January in West Michigan (Rockford/Kent County) is climatologically one of the more reliable windows for snow/ice potential, but many school closures still require either (1) heavy snow with poor timing (overnight into early morning), (2) impactful ice, or (3) extreme cold/wind chills meeting district thresholds. A cold, quiet day with no new snow is usually a normal operating day, even if it feels bitter.
unusual_factors: The region is in an extreme cold episode now (alerts include Extreme Cold Warning/Cold Weather Advisory through Saturday morning, Jan 24, 2026), which increases the chance that any existing moisture becomes persistent black ice.
Very cold air can create “maintenance lag” issues: salt effectiveness drops and compacted snow/ice can remain slick longer than usual, especially on secondary roads.
Your provided Sunday (Jan 25) forecast shows no new snow/precip, but continued subfreezing temperatures and overcast skies—classic for lingering slick spots rather than accumulating snow problems.

local_microclimates: Lake-effect variability: even within Kent County, short-distance changes can occur; however, your Sunday forecast indicates no snow signal, reducing lake-effect closure risk for Monday.
Rural and low-traffic roads around Rockford can stay icy longer than main arterials, especially after prior light freezing rain/snow and during prolonged subfreezing stretches.
Bridges/overpasses and shaded stretches refreeze quickly during clear breaks at night; even under overcast, temperatures are cold enough for refreeze.
infrastructure_considerations: Michigan districts (including West Michigan) typically do not close for minor snow totals alone; impactful ice or a true blizzard/heavy snow timing problem is usually required.
With temps staying well below freezing, crews may plow effectively, but chemical treatment is less effective—so the key risk becomes patchy black ice rather than depth of snow.

If Monday morning wind chills dip to around or below -15°F in the 5–8 AM window (common decision trigger), that can raise the odds of a delay/closure even without snow—especially for districts with long bus rides.
location_specific_factors.elevation_impact: Rockford’s modest terrain variations won’t create mountain-style elevation closures, but small elevation/valley differences can matter for fog/frost and localized refreeze. The bigger driver here is persistent cold and whether any earlier precip left a thin glaze that can linger.

history.confidence_assessment: Based on the provided forecast emphasis (Sunday, Jan 25, 2026: 0 precip/snow, light winds, temps ~7–16°F with wind chills often below 0°F) and the broader pattern (recent snow/freezing rain and extreme cold headlines), the historical analog points to: low snow-day likelihood for Monday, Jan 26, 2026, unless (a) actual Monday-morning wind chills meet local closure thresholds, or (b) there is verified widespread black ice from refreeze/untreated surfaces. In this setup, a NORMAL DAY is more common than a closure; a 2-hour delay is the more plausible disruption than a full snow day if problems develop.

safety_recommendations: Primary snow-day driver is not snowfall but refreeze/black-ice risk: plan for spotty slick patches on bridges, overpasses, and untreated neighborhood roads Monday morning (2026-01-26), especially if any melting occurs Sunday afternoon and refreezes overnight.

Have road commission/school transportation do an early check of typical trouble spots (shaded curves, hilltops, bridge decks, rural/low-traffic roads) between ~5:30–6:30 AM; be ready for targeted salting rather than full plow operations.
Expect the best travel on main arterials; allow extra bus time for subdivisions and backroads where packed snow from prior days can polish into slick surfaces in single-digit temperatures.

Mitigate student exposure risk at stops: wind chills near/below 0°F are plausible with single-digit temps and light wind—ensure winter gear expectations and consider warming-bus practices if delays occur.
Parking lots and sidewalks may remain slick where prior compacted snow/ice exists; prioritize treatment of staff lots, parent drop-off loops, and bus loading zones before arrival times.

infrastructure.overall_clearing_assessment: For Rockford (Kent County, ZIP 49341) on Monday 2026-01-26: a classic 'cold-and-slick' morning rather than a fresh-snow morning. Your forecast shows no new snow on Sunday 2026-01-25, so plow progress depends on clearing residual snow/ice from prior events and maintaining traction in extreme cold. Kent County Road Commission reporting indicates robust staffing (day shift ~90, night shift ~40) and heavy use of abrasives/sand for traction when temperatures are too cold for salt to work well. Expect highways/primaries to be functional for bus routes by ~6:30 AM, but residual slickness/packed snow on neighborhood streets and some secondary roads is the main operational risk. Snow-day likelihood from road conditions alone looks LOW to MODERATE; the stronger cancellation driver would be extreme cold/wind chills (separate from plow-clearing), or if another band of lake-effect snow develops overnight Sunday into early Monday (not shown in the provided Sunday forecast).

final.decision_rationale:
Checklist synthesis (weighted by directive):

1) Expert agreement: All experts converge on a ‘cold-and-slick’ setup with low likelihood of a full closure; the main hazard is residual hard-pack/black ice on secondary/neighborhood roads during 5–9 AM, not a fresh snowstorm.

2) Disagreements/conflicts: Safety/infrastructure flag a moderate commute risk window despite little new precip. Web verification also raised a feels-like discrepancy. I resolved this by tool-checking Monday 5–9 AM wind chills and neighboring-district status: Weather.com shows a minimum near -19°F (not ≤ -20°F), and no confirmed Monday closures in nearby districts.

3) Plow timing math: With no new snow indicated in the provided Sunday forecast, there’s no ‘snow-end-to-7:40 AM’ plow window to compute. Operationally, infrastructure monitoring indicates county primaries are likely passable by ~6:30 AM Monday, with lingering slick spots; local streets remain the largest variability.

4) Any ice? There is no explicit freezing rain signal, but refreeze/black ice risk is moderate due to persistent cold and packed snow/treated surfaces—this supports delays more than full closure.

5) Neighboring districts: No accessible evidence of a Monday 1/26 closure/delay cluster for Rockford-area districts. Prior disruptions (Thu/Fri) are noted but are not, by themselves, a Monday driver.

6) Power outage concerns: Consumers Energy snapshot indicates very low system-wide outages; outage-driven closure is a low-probability tail risk, not the base case.

7) Wind chill verification: Cross-checking sources does NOT confirm ≤ -20°F during the Monday morning commute window; lowest verified value was ~-19°F. That keeps us below the ‘near-automatic’ closure trigger.

8) What would make this wrong? (a) A late-forming lake-effect band overnight Sun→Mon causing a quick 1–3" with poor visibility; (b) verified widespread black ice on bus-route secondaries (not just spotty bridges); (c) a localized school-building power/boiler failure in the extreme cold.

Weighted decision: Meteorology (no new snow/limited wind) anchors low closure odds; safety/infrastructure add a modest bump for hard-pack/black ice; news does not support a closure cascade; power does not support outage-based closure; web verification keeps wind chill just short of the -20°F threshold. Net: 15% for a full snow day (closure).

positions.rationale: From a meteorology-only standpoint, the provided forecast focus for Sunday 2026-01-25 is a cold, dry, stable high-pressure-type setup: overcast, no snow/ice, good visibility, and light winds. That combination is typically *not* a snow-day driver for Monday 2026-01-26 because it lacks the two main closure mechanisms: (1) impactful new precip during the overnight/AM commute window, and (2) strong winds causing blowing/drifting and low visibility. The main remaining weather-related pathway to a closure would be extreme wind chills at bus-stop time or a surprise lake-effect band developing overnight Sun→Mon; neither is supported by the provided Sunday forecast. Therefore I keep the probability low, with a small upward adjustment acknowledging lingering black-ice risk from prior events and the broader cold pattern.
keyFactors: No new precip signal in the provided window (Sun 2026-01-25 shows 0.0" snow / 0.00" QPF; daily snow chance 0%) → no plowing/timing problem heading into Mon morning.
Winds are light (generally ~5–9 mph; max ~8.9 mph) → low blowing/drifting risk and no whiteout/rapid visibility collapse mechanism.

Temperatures are cold but not at the typical “auto-closure” wind-chill level for many West Michigan districts: Sun wind chills mostly around ~-6°F early, rising toward ~0 to +2°F later. Without evidence that Mon 2026-01-26 morning wind chills fall to ~-15°F or colder, cold alone is more “bundle up” than “close.”

Prior-week impacts (Winter Weather Advisory + Extreme Cold Warning Fri 2026-01-23 into Sat 2026-01-24) raise the *background* risk of residual slick spots/black ice, but with no additional precip and light winds, this more often produces delays/extra caution than a full closure.

Overcast + very cold temps favor persistence of packed snow/ice, but absent fresh snowfall or freezing rain, conditions usually trend stable/improving rather than deteriorating into the Mon decision window.

positions.rationale: I’m anchoring on the dominant late‑January operational pattern for West Michigan: once the heavy snow/ice phase passes and you enter a cold, dry, high‑pressure regime, districts usually run—sometimes with a delay if transportation reports widespread slickness before dawn. With Sunday (2026-01-25) showing no new precip and light winds, the historical closure base rate is low, so I land at **14%** for a full snow day on **Mon 2026-01-26** (with a higher chance of a delay than a closure).
keyFactors: **Historical analog (“post–Arctic blast, dry/overcast”):** In West Michigan, the most common outcome after the main snow/ice ends is **school as normal**—even if it’s bitterly cold—because roads have had time to be treated and there’s no new accumulation/timing problem.

**No fresh precip signal in the provided lead‑in forecast (Sun 2026-01-25):** Historically, snow days cluster around **overnight-to-AM snow/ice** events. With **0 precip / 0 snow** in the lead-in period, the ‘classic’ closure driver isn’t present.

**Cold-alone closures are comparatively rare:** The region *will* be cold, but the strongest NWS “Extreme Cold Warning” in the dataset is **for Fri 2026-01-23 into Sat 2026-01-24**, not Monday. Without evidence that **Mon 2026-01-26** wind chills hit common district thresholds, history says closures are **possible but not the baseline** outcome.

**Residual slick/black ice is the main tail risk:** Prior light freezing rain/snow + very cold temps can preserve slick spots (bridges, rural connectors). Historically, that produces **more delays than full closures**, unless it’s widespread and verified early AM.

**Regional severity signals are real but decaying:** Nearby disruptions (e.g., Fri 2026-01-23 closures/cancellations) indicate the episode is significant, but history says **closure likelihood drops** once you get 24–48 hours into a dry, stable cold pattern.
Derived from primary analysis

positions.rationale: As the news specialist, I weight (a) official district comms, (b) neighboring-district actions, and (c) whether there’s an ongoing/expanding event that typically produces a wave of Sunday-night/Monday-morning closures. With Sunday forecast showing no new snow/ice and only modest winds, the most plausible disruption is a delay for isolated slick spots rather than a full snow day. I land at a low-but-nonzero probability to account for “surprise” refreeze/black-ice reports or an operational issue (e.g., localized power/heat), which are not well-captured by the current news scan.

Historically, **moderate** ice risk more often yields **localized crashes and a delay** than a district-wide closure. Can you clarify what would make it *widespread* (e.g., known melting Sunday afternoon + refreeze, or documented glazing from prior freezing rain) rather than ‘spotty’—since that distinction is what moves us from ~10–20% to ~30%+?

debates.topic: Neighboring-district closures on Fri 2026-01-23 are a useful ‘severity’ signal, but historically they can overweight the probability for Monday if the forcing event ends and roads stabilize. Any evidence of **Sunday night** pre-emptive messaging, transportation route checks, or staffing constraints would be more predictive for Monday than Thurs/Fri disruptions.
debates.challenge: Neighboring-district closures on Fri 2026-01-23 are a useful ‘severity’ signal, but historically they can overweight the probability for Monday if the forcing event ends and roads stabilize. Any evidence of **Sunday night** pre-emptive messaging, transportation route checks, or staffing constraints would be more predictive for Monday than Thurs/Fri disruptions.

debates.topic: Your conclusion is directionally right (no new precip), but it leans heavily on Sunday (1/25) data while the target decision is Monday (1/26). If Monday morning brings even light snow showers or lower wind chills than expected, the closure odds can jump—please confirm Monday-specific hour-by-hour and any lake-effect potential.
debates.challenge: Your conclusion is directionally right (no new precip), but it leans heavily on Sunday (1/25) data while the target decision is Monday (1/26). If Monday morning brings even light snow showers or lower wind chills than expected, the closure odds can jump—please confirm Monday-specific hour-by-hour and any lake-effect potential.

debates.topic: The risk window you cite (Mon 5–9 AM) implies a commute hazard, but the current dataset doesn’t show Monday precip or a verified melt/refreeze mechanism on Sunday (temps stay below freezing). Clarify what specific pathway produces widespread black ice vs isolated spots; otherwise the ‘moderate’ label may be overstated for cancellation likelihood.
debates.challenge: The risk window you cite (Mon 5–9 AM) implies a commute hazard, but the current dataset doesn’t show Monday precip or a verified melt/refreeze mechanism on Sunday (temps stay below freezing). Clarify what specific pathway produces widespread black ice vs isolated spots; otherwise the ‘moderate’ label may be overstated for cancellation likelihood.

debates.topic: Our news scan has a known blind spot: a closings aggregator returned 403 and social media buzz was limited. That can undercount informal closure planning. We should compensate by slightly widening uncertainty (especially Sunday night) but not by assuming closures are likely.
debates.challenge: Our news scan has a known blind spot: a closings aggregator returned 403 and social media buzz was limited. That can undercount informal closure planning. We should compensate by slightly widening uncertainty (especially Sunday night) but not by assuming closures are likely.

positions.rationale: Meteorology-only: this looks like a post-event, cold, stable regime with overcast skies and *no* forecast snowfall/ice on Sunday (the last pre-school day). That removes the main closure mechanism in West Michigan: impactful accumulation or ice during the overnight-to-morning window. Winds/visibility also do not support hazardous travel from blowing snow. Therefore, a full snow day on Monday 2026-01-26 is unlikely. I raise my prior 8% modestly to 12% to respect peers’ emphasis on residual slickness (very cold pavement + salt underperformance + hard-pack persistence) and the nonzero chance of a lake-effect/forecast bust that isn’t captured in the Sunday-only focus.
keyFactors: No new precip signal in the provided period leading into Monday: Sunday 2026-01-25 shows 0.00" liquid, 0 cm snow, and 0% snow chance all day/hourly—this strongly suppresses true “snow day” risk (no plow-timing problem).
Light winds (generally ~5–9 mph, gusts mostly <20–25 mph) + good visibility (~6+ miles) → low blowing/drifting/whiteout risk for the Monday AM commute.

Temperatures remain well below freezing (roughly 7–16°F on Sunday) so any existing snowpack/compacted snow will not melt away; this increases the *persistence* of slick spots but doesn’t create new widespread hazard by itself.

Wind chills are cold but not clearly at the common “automatic closure” tier for many MI districts (the Extreme Cold Warning in the dataset expires Sat 2026-01-24 11:00 AM; we are not shown a Mon 2026-01-26 warning).

The only plausible meteorology-driven pathway to a Monday closure, given “no new precip,” is widespread refreeze/black ice from prior moisture and/or a forecast miss (e.g., an unexpected lake-effect band overnight Sun→Mon). Those are low-probability but nonzero.

positions.rationale:
**My updated snow-day (full closure) probability for Rockford, MI on Monday 2026-01-26 is 16%.**

I’m moving slightly up from my prior 14% after considering the **cluster of operational-disruption signals** in the region (Fri closures nearby; extreme cold episode) and the reality that **packed snow + prolonged subfreezing temps** can keep secondary roads slick longer than people expect.

But I’m still well below the Safety agent’s 40% because the *dominant historical driver* for full closures—new accumulating snow/ice timed into Sunday night → Monday morning—**is not present in the provided forecast focus** (Sun 2026-01-25 is dry and relatively light-wind). In this pattern, the most common outcome historically is **school open**, with the main upside risk being a **2-hour delay** if early route checks show widespread black ice/hardpack on neighborhood streets and rural connectors.

So: low likelihood of a full snow day, but non-trivial “tail risk” from residual slickness and cold-related operations.
keyFactors: **Historical analog / base rate:** In West Michigan, once you shift from an active snow/ice event into a cold, dry, high‑pressure regime (overcast, light wind, no new precip), **full closures become uncommon**; districts typically operate and sometimes call a **delay** if early-morning road checks find widespread slickness.

**No fresh-precip trigger:** The provided forecast focus for Sun 2026-01-25 shows **0 precip / 0 snow** and light winds—historically this removes the #1 driver of Monday closures (overnight snow/ice during the decision window).

**“Tail risk” from prior wintry weather:** There *was* active winter weather and extreme cold alerts Fri 2026-01-23 into Sat 2026-01-24. Historically, that raises the chance of a Monday disruption via **hard‑pack/black ice** lingering on subdivisions, bridges, and rural connectors—especially with temps staying well below freezing (limited melt + salt effectiveness issues).

**Cold alone usually ≠ closure (but can create delays):** Extreme Cold Warning ends Sat 2026-01-24 11:00 AM; for Mon 2026-01-26 we don’t have confirmed wind chills in the “district-threshold” territory (often nearer to -20°F or worse). So cold is a supporting risk factor, not a primary closure driver here.

**Peer-signal moderation:** Safety’s 40% seems to be weighting “moderate” refreeze risk heavily; historically, that tends to produce **delays more than full closures** unless there’s evidence of widespread glaze/untreated ice on many routes.

positions.rationale: As the safety specialist, I’m downgrading from my prior 40% to **18%** for a *full snow day* Monday 2026-01-26. The peer analyses (meteorology 8%, history 14%, news 12%) correctly emphasize that the forecast shown is cold/dry with light winds and no new accumulation—conditions that typically do not warrant a full closure in West Michigan. My remaining upward adjustment above the peer cluster is purely safety/operations-driven: persistent extreme cold can keep secondary roads polished and increase black-ice risk in the 5–9 AM window, and the consequences of a localized outage/heat issue are higher in single-digit temps. However, absent evidence of widespread ice or an active warning covering Monday morning, the most likely outcome is a normal day (possibly with localized slick spots and/or a delay decision if early route checks look bad).
keyFactors: No new precip signal in the provided Sunday (2026-01-25) forecast: 0" snow / 0 precip, good visibility, light winds—this removes the most common full-closure driver (overnight snow/ice during the Monday AM decision window).

Cold-but-not-threshold-looking for full closure: Sunday temps ~7–16°F with wind chills generally around/just below 0°F; the NWS Extreme Cold Warning in the packet expires Saturday 2026-01-24 11:00 AM, so the dataset does not show a Monday-morning wind-chill trigger on its face.

Residual slickness pathway exists: prolonged subfreezing conditions can preserve hard-pack and create patchy black ice (bridges/ramps/shaded neighborhood roads). That is a *delay* driver more often than a *full snow day* driver unless it’s widespread on bus routes.

Operational “tail risks” remain: localized power/heat failures in extreme cold, or a surprise lake-effect band not captured in the Sunday-focused forecast could force a closure, but those are not supported strongly by current data.

positions.rationale: Netting the news/operations signals together: we have evidence of impactful conditions earlier in the period (Thu/Fri) and active winter operations, but we do **not** have (a) a continuing storm signal into Monday, (b) a cluster of Sunday-night district pre-announcements, or (c) widespread closure chatter. With Sunday 1/25 forecast dry and winds modest, the most likely school outcome for Monday 1/26 is normal operations, with a smaller chance of a 2-hour delay if black ice is reported on bus routes early Monday. I’m keeping the full ‘snow day’ probability low but nonzero to account for residual-slick-road reports, localized infrastructure issues (heating/power), or a last-minute decision if conditions deteriorate unexpectedly overnight.
keyFactors: No Rockford Public Schools (MI) closure/delay announcement visible yet for Monday, 2026-01-26; in my experience, if a full closure is likely from a known storm, you often start seeing at least “monitoring conditions” language by Sunday afternoon/evening.

The most relevant official/regional signals (Forest Hills after-school cancellations on Thu 1/22/2026; Sparta closed Fri 1/23/2026) indicate **recent** severity, but don’t (by themselves) indicate a continuing precip event into Mon 1/26.
Forecast context for Sun 1/25: **0 precip / 0 snow**, light winds, good visibility. That weakens the typical “Sunday night → Monday morning closure wave” mechanism.
Main plausible disruption pathway is **refreeze/black ice** from prior events + persistent subfreezing temps (i.e., a **delay** is more plausible than a full cancellation).
No notable community ‘buzz’ / closings chatter captured; also no power outage signal captured (which can sometimes drive cold-weather closures even without new snow).

If the argument is black ice, can you specify a meteorological trigger for *widespread* glaze Sunday night (e.g., fog/freezing drizzle, melt-refreeze window, or measurable precip) rather than isolated trouble spots? Without that, this looks more like a ‘delay’ risk than a full closure risk.

alert.headline: Hydrologic Outlook issued January 22 at 11:14AM EST by NWS Grand Rapids MI
alert.areas: Allegan, MI; Barry, MI; Calhoun, MI; Clare, MI; Clinton, MI; Eaton, MI; Gratiot, MI; Ingham, MI; Ionia, MI; Isabella, MI; Jackson, MI; Kalamazoo, MI; Kent, MI; Lake, MI; Mason, MI; Mecosta, MI; Montcalm, MI; Muskegon, MI; Newaygo, MI; Oceana, MI; Osceola, MI; Ottawa, MI; Van Buren, MI
alert.desc:
ESFGRR

Bitterly cold temperatures moving into Michigan over the next few
days will increase the risk of ice jams on rivers. While many
locations have already frozen over, ongoing ice growth will continue
to increase in any open water areas.

These temperatures have not been seen for many years in West
Michigan, which means that some areas that don't typically
experience river ice jams may have issues this year. Ice jams can
result in water levels rising much more quickly than usual, which
can catch people off guard. Anyone living or working near rivers in
West Michigan should prepare now for potential river ice and rising
water levels.

While temperatures warm up a bit early next week, this overall cold
weather pattern will continue through at least next week, which will
keep ice locked in place on the rivers.


You can always find the latest river level information at water.noaa.
gov

alert.headline: Winter Weather Advisory issued January 23 at 9:30AM EST until January 23 at 7:00PM EST by NWS Grand Rapids MI
alert.areas: Mason; Lake; Oceana; Newaygo; Muskegon; Ottawa; Kent; Allegan; Barry; Van Buren; Kalamazoo
alert.desc:
* WHAT...Snow. Additional snow accumulations up to one inch, locally
higher, mainly along the lakeshore.

* WHERE...Portions of southwest and west central Michigan.

* WHEN...Until 7 PM EST this evening.

* IMPACTS...Roads, and especially bridges and overpasses, will
likely become slick and hazardous. Visibility and road conditions
may change rapidly over short distances in lake effect snow. Plan
on slippery road conditions. The hazardous conditions could impact
the Friday evening commute.
alert.instruction:
Slow down and use caution while traveling.

During lake effect snow, the weather can vary from bands of locally
heavy snow to dry weather just a few miles away. Visibilities can
also vary greatly. Be prepared for rapid changes in weather,
visibility, and road conditions.

alert.headline: Extreme Cold Warning issued January 23 at 9:28AM EST until January 24 at 11:00AM EST by NWS Grand Rapids MI
alert.areas: Mason; Lake; Osceola; Clare; Oceana; Newaygo; Mecosta; Isabella; Muskegon; Montcalm; Gratiot; Ottawa; Kent; Ionia; Clinton
alert.desc:
* WHAT...Dangerously cold wind chills as low as 25 to 30 below zero.

* WHERE...Portions of central, south central, southwest, and west
central Michigan.

* WHEN...Until 11 AM EST Saturday.

* IMPACTS...The dangerously cold wind chills as low as 25 to 30
below zero could cause frostbite on exposed skin in 30 minutes or
less. Frostbite and hypothermia will occur if unprotected skin is
exposed to these temperatures. An extended period of freezing
temperatures could cause ruptured water pipes.
alert.instruction:
Avoid outside activities if possible. When outside, make sure you
wear appropriate clothing, a hat, and gloves.

alert.headline: Cold Weather Advisory issued January 23 at 9:28AM EST until January 24 at 11:00AM EST by NWS Grand Rapids MI
alert.areas: Allegan; Barry; Eaton; Ingham; Van Buren; Kalamazoo; Calhoun; Jackson
alert.desc:
* WHAT...Very cold wind chills as low as 20 to 25 below zero.

* WHERE...Calhoun, Eaton, Ingham, Jackson, Allegan, Barry,
Kalamazoo, and Van Buren Counties.

* WHEN...Until 11 AM EST Saturday.

* IMPACTS...The dangerously cold wind chills as low as 20 to 25
below zero could cause frostbite on exposed skin in as little as
30 minutes. Frostbite and hypothermia will occur if unprotected
skin is exposed to these temperatures.
alert.instruction:
Use caution while outdoors. Wear appropriate clothing, a hat, and
gloves.

Keep pets indoors as much as possible.

Make frequent checks on older family, friends, and neighbors. Ensure
portable heaters are used correctly. Do not use generators or grills
inside.
